sn22.8:1.2: “Mendicants, I will teach you how grasping leads to anxiety, and how not grasping leads to freedom from anxiety.
sn22.8:1.3: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.
sn22.8:1.4: And how does grasping lead to anxiety?
sn22.8:1.5: It’s when an uneducated ordinary person regards form like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’
sn22.8:1.6: But that form of theirs decays and perishes,
sn22.8:1.7: which gives rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn22.8:1.11: consciousness like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’
sn22.8:1.12: But that consciousness of theirs decays and perishes,
sn22.8:1.13: which gives rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn22.8:1.14: That’s how grasping leads to anxiety.
sn22.8:2.1: And how does not grasping lead to freedom from anxiety?
sn22.8:2.2: It’s when an educated noble disciple regards form like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn22.8:2.3: When that form of theirs decays and perishes,
sn22.8:2.4: it doesn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn22.8:2.8: consciousness like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
sn22.8:2.9: When that consciousness of theirs decays and perishes,
sn22.8:2.10: it doesn’t give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
sn22.8:2.11: That’s how not grasping leads to freedom from anxiety.”
